Utterance: Hi there! It’s great to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hey, Ellie. I’ve had a pretty good week, actually. I’ve been trying to stick to the meditation and sleep routine.
That’s wonderful to hear! How has it been going for you?
The meditation in the morning has helped me feel a bit more centered throughout the day. I still struggle with sleep, but I think it’s getting a little better.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: That’s a fantastic start! It’s great that you’re noticing some positive changes. Have you been able to incorporate any relaxation exercises before bed?
Yeah, I’ve been doing some light stretching and breathing exercises. It helps a bit.
Excellent! It sounds like you’re developing a healthy routine. Have you noticed any changes in your mood or anger levels?
Actually, yeah. I’ve been a bit less irritable. I think the meditation is helping with that.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Mental Health Observations

Utterance: That’s great progress! It’s encouraging to see you finding ways to manage your emotions. Have you had any conflicts with your mom recently?
Not since our last argument. I’ve been trying to keep the peace.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That’s a wise choice. Sometimes, stepping back can help create a calmer environment. Have you had any conversations with her about your concerns regarding her health?
I did suggest we cook together, and we made a healthy dinner last weekend. She seemed to appreciate it.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That’s wonderful! It sounds like you’re taking positive steps to connect with her. How did that make you feel?
It felt good. I think she enjoyed spending time together.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That’s so important. Building those connections can be very beneficial for both of you. Is there anything else you’d like to explore today?
I’ve been thinking about my dad a lot lately. I still feel a lot of anger towards him for how he treated me and my dog.
That’s a heavy burden to carry. It’s okay to feel angry about past experiences. Have you found any ways to process those feelings?
Not really. I just try to push it aside, but it keeps coming back.
It’s understandable to want to avoid those feelings, but sometimes facing them can be helpful. Would you be open to exploring those feelings more deeply?
I guess so. I just don’t know where to start.
We can start by talking about specific memories that come to mind when you think of your dad. What stands out to you?
I remember a time when he was really angry and took it out on my dog. I felt so powerless.
That sounds incredibly painful. It’s natural to feel anger and sadness about that experience. Have you ever had the chance to express that anger in a safe way?
No, I usually just keep it bottled up.

It might be helpful to find a constructive outlet for that anger. Some people find it useful to write about their feelings or even engage in physical activity to release pent-up energy. What do you think?
Writing could be good. I’ve never really tried that before.
It could be a helpful way to process your feelings without feeling overwhelmed. Would you be willing to give it a try?
Yeah, I can try writing about it.
Great! Let’s check in on that progress next time. Have you noticed any other emotions surfacing in your life lately?
I’ve had moments of sadness, especially when I think about my past.
That’s completely understandable. It’s important to honor those feelings. Have you found any coping strategies that help during those times?
I usually call my girlfriend, and she helps me feel better.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That’s wonderful! It’s great to have someone supportive in your life. Remember, it’s okay to lean on others when you’re feeling down.
Thanks, Ellie. I appreciate your support.
Of course! I’m here to help you navigate these feelings. Let’s set a goal for writing about your feelings and checking in on your sleep routine for next week.
Sounds good to me.
I look forward to hearing about your experiences. Take care until then!
Bye, Ellie!
